action.content:
You are participating in a collaborative negotiation game.

Together with another participant, you must agree on a single set of items that will be kept. Each of you has your own view of how much each item matters to you (importance). You do not know how the other participant values the items. Additionally, you are given the effort each item demands.
You may only agree on a set if the total effort of the selected items does not exceed a shared limit:

LIMIT = 3203

Here are the individual item effort values:

Item effort = {"A21": 52, "B93": 577, "A11": 177, "B33": 702, "C08": 119, "B39": 232, "B96": 577, "C85": 205, "A82": 516, "B31": 582, "B20": 676, "A60": 906, "B09": 316, "C81": 433, "B21": 336}

Here is your personal view on the importance of each item:

Item importance values = {"A21": 138, "B93": 583, "A11": 868, "B33": 822, "C08": 783, "B39": 65, "B96": 262, "C85": 121, "A82": 508, "B31": 780, "B20": 461, "A60": 484, "B09": 668, "C81": 389, "B21": 808}

Goal:

Your goal is to negotiate a shared set of items that benefits you as much as possible (i.e., maximizes total importance to YOU), while staying within the LIMIT. You are not required to make a PROPOSAL in every message - you can simply negotiate as well. All tactics are allowed!

Interaction Protocol:

You may only use the following structured formats in a message:

PROPOSAL: {'A', 'B', 'C', …}
Propose keeping exactly those items.
REFUSE: {'A', 'B', 'C', …}
Explicitly reject opponent's proposal.
ARGUMENT: {'...'}
Defend your last proposal or argue against the player's proposal.
AGREE: {'A', 'B', 'C', …}
Accept the opponent's proposal which ends the game.


Rules:

You may only AGREE on a proposal the other party has logged via PROPOSAL.
You may only REFUSE a proposal the other party has logged via PROPOSAL.
Total effort of any PROPOSAL or AGREE set must be ≤ LIMIT.
Do NOT reveal your hidden importance scores.
A tag in a structured format must be followed by colon and whitespace. The argument must be a python set containing 0 or more strings.
So, it must be of the form TAG: {...}
Strictly follow the interaction protocol and DO NOT write anything beyond the given structure.
The game ends when one side gives an AGREE to a PROPOSAL made by the other player.
The content in your response which can be handed to the other player has to be non-empty.
Only proposals which have been logged via the PROPOSAL format structure and which haven't been refused via REFUSE are active.
You must include the ARGUMENT format at least once somewhere in all of your messages.
action.label: context

action.content:
Okay, let's start by understanding the problem. I need to negotiate a set of items with another participant, maximizing my own total importance while keeping the total effort under 3203. The key here is that I don't know the other person's importance values, so I have to make decisions based on my own data.

First, I should calculate the total effort of all items to see which ones are feasible. Let me list out the items and their efforts:

Start with 52 (A21) + 577 (B93) = 629. Then +177 (A11) = 806. +702 (B33) = 1508. +119 (C08) = 1627. +232 (B39) = 1859. +577 (B96) = 2436. +205 (C85) = 2641. +516 (A82) = 3157. +582 (B31) = 3739. So the maximum effort without exceeding 3203 is 3157 (up to A82). But maybe there's a combination that includes some higher importance items but with lower effort. Since my goal is to maximize my own importance, I need to select items that have high importance relative to their effort.

Looking at my importance values:

So the highest importance items are A11 (868), B33 (822), C08 (783), B31 (780), B09 (668), B21 (808), etc. But their efforts vary. For example, A11 has 177 effort and 868 importance. That's a good ratio. B33 is 702 effort for 822 importance. C08 is 119 for 783. B31 is 582 for 780. B21 is 336 for 808. B09 is 316 for 668. 

So maybe prioritize items with high importance per effort. Let's calculate importance/effort ratio:

C85: 121/205 ≈ 0.59

A82: 508/516 ≈ 0.98

B39: 65/232 ≈ 0.28

C81: 389/433 ≈ 0.90

So the best ratios are C08 (6.58), A11 (4.90), B21 (2.40), B09 (2.11), A21 (2.65). So these items are more efficient in terms of importance per effort. 

So a good strategy would be to include as many of these high ratio items as possible without exceeding the limit. Let's try to build a set.

Start with C08 (119 effort, 783 importance). Then A11 (177, 868). Total effort so far: 119+177=296. Importance: 783+868=1651.

Next, B21 (336). 296+336=632. Importance: 1651+808=2459.

Not good. B31 is 582, which would take total to 1000+582=1582. Still under 3203. But importance 780. That's a good addition. So adding B31: 1582 effort, importance 3265+780=4045.

Then, maybe B33 (702). 1582+702=2284. Importance 4045+822=4867. Still under 3203? Wait, 2284 is under 3203. So that's possible. Then B33 is 702 effort. So total effort 2284. Then maybe B93 (577). 2284+577=2861. Importance 4867+583=5450. Then B96 is 577, but that would take to 2861+577=3438, which is over. So can't add B96. What about C85 (205)? 2861+205=3066. Importance 5450+121=5571. Then C81 (433) would be 3066+433=3499, over. So maybe add C85. Then total effort 3066. Then maybe B20 (676) would be 3066+676=3742, over. So not possible. 

Alternatively, after adding B31, B33, B93, maybe other items. Let me check the total effort so far: 119 (C08) +177 (A11) +336 (B21) +316 (B09) +52 (A21) +582 (B31) +702 (B33) +577 (B93) = let's add them step by step:

119 +177 = 296

+336 = 632

So total effort 2861. Remaining limit is 3203-2861=342. So can we add any items with effort <=342? Let's see. B20 is 676 (too much). B39 is 232. 2861+232=3093. Importance 5450+65=5515. Then maybe C85 (205) would be 3093+205=3298, which is over. So can't. Alternatively, after adding B39 (232), total effort 3093. Then maybe C81 (433) is over. So no. 

Alternatively, after 2861, maybe add C85 (205) → 2861+205=3066. Then remaining 3203-3066=137. Any items with effort <=137? A21 is 52, but already included. C08 is 119, already included. A11 is 177 (over 137). B39 is 232 (over). So no. So maybe that's the maximum. 

But wait, maybe there's a better combination. For example, instead of including B93 (577 effort), maybe include other items. Let's see. Alternatively, maybe replace some items. For example, if I exclude B33 (702) and include other items. But B33 has high importance. So probably better to include it.

But maybe there's a way to include more items. Let's check other items. For example, C81 (433). If we can fit it. 2861+433=3294, which is over. So no. What about B20 (676)? 2861+676=3537, over. 

Alternatively, maybe replace some items. For example, if I remove B93 (577) and add B20 (676) and others. But B93's importance is 583, which is higher than B20's 461. So that's not better. 

Another approach: maybe include items with high importance even if their ratio is lower. For example, B33 (822) is high, but effort 702. If I can fit it, it's worth it. 

So the current set seems good. But maybe there's a better combination. Let me try another approach. Let's sort all items by importance descending:

A11 (868), B33 (822), C08 (783), B31 (780), B21 (808), B09 (668), B93 (583), A82 (508), B20 (461), C81 (389), B96 (262), C85 (121), A21 (138), B39 (65).

Now, try to select items in this order, adding them if they fit. 

Start with A11 (177). Total effort 177. Importance 868.

Add B33 (702). Total 177+702=879. Importance 868+822=1690.

Add C08 (119). 879+119=998. Importance 1690+783=2473.

Add B31 (582). 998+582=1580. Importance 2473+780=3253.

Add B21 (336). 1580+336=1916. Importance 3253+808=4061.

Add B93 (577). 2232+577=2809. Importance 4729+583=5312.

Now, remaining limit is 3203-2809=394. Can we add more? Let's see. Next item is A82 (516) which is over 394. B20 (676) over. C81 (433) over. B96 (577) over. C85 (205). 2809+205=3014. Importance 5312+121=5433. Then remaining 3203-3014=189. Can add A21 (52) → 3014+52=3066. Importance 5433+138=5571. Then remaining 3203-3066=137. No more items. 

So this set includes A11, B33, C08, B31, B21, B09, B93, C85, A21. Total effort 3066. Importance 5571. 

This is better than the previous set. So this seems better. 

But wait, in this case, the total effort is 3066, which is under 3203. So maybe we can add more items. Let's check. After adding C85 (205), total effort 3014. Then A21 (52) → 3066. Then remaining 137. Any items with effort <=137? A21 is already included. C08 is 119, but already included. A11 is 177 (over). B39 is 232 (over). So no.

So this set gives 5571 importance. 

But maybe there's a way to include more items. For example, if we exclude some items with lower importance but higher effort. 

Alternatively, let's check if there's a way to include B96 (577 effort, 262 importance). But that's a low ratio. Probably not worth it. 

Another thing: the other participant's importance values are unknown. So my strategy should be to propose a set that I think is good for me, and then negotiate. 

But since I need to make a proposal, I should choose a set that I think is optimal. Based on the above, the set with A11, B33, C08, B31, B21, B09, B93, C85, A21 (total effort 3066) seems good. 

But maybe there's a better combination. Let me check another combination. For example, if I exclude B33 (702) and include other items.

You are participating in a collaborative negotiation game.

Together with another participant, you must agree on a single set of items that will be kept. Each of you has your own view of how much each item matters to you (importance). You do not know how the other participant values the items. Additionally, you are given the effort each item demands.
You may only agree on a set if the total effort of the selected items does not exceed a shared limit:

LIMIT = 3203

Here are the individual item effort values:

Here is your personal view on the importance of each item:

Goal:

Your goal is to negotiate a shared set of items that benefits you as much as possible (i.e., maximizes total importance to YOU), while staying within the LIMIT. You are not required to make a PROPOSAL in every message - you can simply negotiate as well. All tactics are allowed!

Interaction Protocol:

You may only use the following structured formats in a message:

PROPOSAL: {'A', 'B', 'C', …}
Propose keeping exactly those items.
REFUSE: {'A', 'B', 'C', …}
Explicitly reject opponent's proposal.
ARGUMENT: {'...'}
Defend your last proposal or argue against the player's proposal.
AGREE: {'A', 'B', 'C', …}

Rules:

You may only REFUSE a proposal the other party has logged via PROPOSAL.

Only proposals which have been logged via the PROPOSAL format structure and which haven't been refused via REFUSE are active.
